data.question: He maintained that Nigerians need a leader with an <u>iron fist</u>
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Iron fist is used in reference to the exercise of power in an oppressive or ruthless way. A particularly severe, forceful, and uncompromising manner of ruling/governing.

data.question: The emphasis placed on good moral conduct by the society in the past seems to have been <u>relaxed</u>
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: relax: make or become less tense or anxious.

data.question: The matter was considered a <u>private</u> concern of the chairman to handle
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Private: belonging to or for the use of one particular person or group of people only.

data.question: He was underrated at the <u>preliminary</u> stage of the competition
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Preliminary: preceding or done in preparation for something fuller or more important.

data.question: The office assistant was dismissed for <u>pilfering</u>
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: PIlfering: steal (things of little value).

data.question: Almost everyone she had worked with took advantage of her <u>meekness</u>
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Meekness: the fact or condition of being meek; submissiveness.

data.question: Barely six months after his father's demise, he has nothing left again of his <u>patrimony</u>
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Patrimony: property inherited from one's father or male ancestor. Also, valued things passed down from previous generations.

data.question:
choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.

His grandfather was one of the few <u>patriotic</u> Nigerians who ever lived.
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Patriotic: having or expressing devotion to and vigorous support for one's country. It also implies showing love for your country and being proud of it

data.question: Many people believed that such an action is <u>unbecoming</u> of a leader
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Unbecoming: (of behaviour) not fitting or appropriate; unseemly.

data.question: The governor was <u>incoherent</u> in his speech
data.section: choose the most appropriate option nearest in meaning to the word(s) underlined.
data.solution: Incoherent: (of spoken or written language) expressed in an incomprehensible or confusing way; unclear.

data.question: The lady has devised a means of <u>tackling</u> her current challenges.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Tackling: make determined efforts to deal with (a problem or difficult task).

Avoiding: keep away from or stop oneself from doing (something).

data.question: One hundred and forty kilometres per hour is a <u>reasonable</u> speed limit.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Reasonable:as much as is appropriate or fair; moderate.

Outrageous: shockingly bad or excessive.

data.question: The annual festival attracts <u>dignitaries</u> from both home and abroad.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Dignitary: a person considered to be important because of high rank or office.

nonentity: a person or thing with no special or interesting qualities; an unimportant person or thing.

data.question: The soldiers were <u>remorseful</u> for their inhuman treatment of the civilians.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Remorseful: filled with remorse; sorry.

Boastful: showing excessive pride and self-satisfaction in one's achievements, possessions, or abilities.

data.question: nsecurity has <u>escalated</u> since the present government came into power.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Escalate: increase rapidly.

Abate: (of something unpleasant or severe) become less intense or widespread

data.question: It is <u>embarrassing</u> to accept our mistakes and tender an apology.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Embarrassing: causing embarrassment.

Honourable: bringing or deserving honour.

data.question: The lawmakers are perceived to be the <u>greediest</u> set of politicians.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Greedy: Having or showing a strong or excessive desire to acquire money or possess things,

Selfless: concerned more with the needs and wishes of others than with one's own; unselfish.

data.question: James found the photocopied material <u>invaluable</u> while preparing for the examination
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Invaluable: extremely useful; indispensable.

worthless: having no real value or use.

data.question: Mr. Akin's health has greatly <u>degenerated</u> in the last week.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Degenerated: decline or deteriorate physically, mentally, or morally.

improved: having become or been made better.

data.question: The incumbent president <u>conceded</u> defeat before the final result was announced.
data.section: choose the option nearly opposite in meaning to the word(s) underlined
data.solution:
Concede: admit or agree that something is true after first denying or resisting it.

Reject: refuse to agree to (a request).

data.question: The Parents Teachers Association promised to build a CAFETERIA.

option.a: Does the alumni association promised to build a cafeteria?
option.b: Does the school authority promised to build a library?
option.c: Did the parents teachers association promise to build a library?
option.d: Does the parents teachers association promised to demolish a cafeteria?

data.section: choose the option that best answers the question from the options lettered A-D
data.solution:
Option C is the correct answer because CAFETERIA contradicts the word 'library'. The interrogative statement, therefore, provides a chance to emphasize the word CAFETERIA.

Did the parents teachers association promise to build a library? No, The Parents Teachers Association promised to build a CAFETERIA.

data.question: He SLAPPED the teacher.
data.section: choose the option that best answers the question from the options lettered A-D
data.solution:
Option A is the correct answer because SLAPPED contradicts the word 'greet'. The interrogative statement, therefore, provides a chance to emphasize the word slapped.

Did he greet the teacher? NO, he slapped the teacher.
